p: Second, the exercise did not include any specific measures to discover highly neglected yet more impactful questions. Goodwin and Wright [ 68] analysed a range of forecasting methods and found that none sufficiently incorporated measures to anticipate low-probability, high-impact events. They suggest incorporating intentional devil’s advocates (intentionally and directly challenging a predominant view for the sake of debate) to overcome frame blindness—ovesights in common ways of viewing and predicting problems—and create more radical and unforeseen ideas. A future version of a biological security questions workshop could use such recommendations to better elaborate questions concerning low-probability, high-impact events.
